paper_abstract: Botnets continue to be used by attackers to perform various malicious activities on the Internet. Over the past years, many botnet detection techniques have been proposed; however, most of them cannot detect botnets in an early stage of their lifecycle, or they often depend on a specific command and control protocol. In this paper, we propose BotGrab, a general botnet detection system that considers both malicious activities and the history of coordinated group activities in the network to identify bot-infected hosts. BotGrab tracks suspected hosts participating in some coordinated group activities and calculates a negative reputation score for each of them based on the history of their participation in these activities. A suspected host will be identified as being bot-infected if it has a high negative reputation score or performs some malicious activities while having a low negative reputation score. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BotGrab to detect various botnets including HTTP-, IRC-, and P2P-based botnets using a testbed network consisting of some bot-infected hosts. paper_title: BotGrab: A negative reputation system for botnet detection
